awd_titl_txt: SCH: EXP: Collaborative Research: Cognitive Haptic Based Rehabilitation System for Patient-Centric Home
awd_abstract_narration:
This project is funded under a joint solicitation between the National Science Foundation and the National Institutes of Health, named "Smart and Connected Health" (SCH), which aims to accelerate the development and use of innovative approaches that would support the much needed transformation of healthcare across the entire population. Stroke is the leading cause of disability among older adults in the United States. More than 800,000 strokes occur each year and nearly one third of all stroke survivors have significant residual disability, with older individuals generally experiencing slower functional recovery. Current physical rehabilitation of such patients is primarily hospital centric. However, due to economic pressures on the U.S. health care system, stroke patients are receiving less therapy and going home after few months of acute therapy without regaining the whole functionality of their body. Moreover, many patients who have completed their acute in-patient rehabilitation following a stroke or other injury may have limited access to out-patient rehabilitation upon their return home. These patients can benefit from access and quality of care through home-based rehabilitations. The success of the home-based therapy is highly dependent on monitoring the patient compliance and designing the home-based rehabilitation that can mentally engaged the subjects. The proposed research approaches the above stated problem with two novel propositions by developing a haptic-based rehabilitation system that can be used at home. 

The project is carried out as follows: First, a haptic home-based system is developed to rehabilitate Activity of Daily Living (ADL) skills in both the affected and the non-dominant/unaffected upper limb of a patient whose dominant upper limbs has been affected by some disability. Second, the research investigates the use of home centered cognitive haptic therapy by monitoring the patient's brain activity. The proposed system uses cognitive and haptic feedbacks to monitor the progress of patient and his or her engagement and adapts itself accordingly. Patient's recovery progress is evaluated through combination of 1) scores related to accuracy and completion of task and 2) subject's level of mental engagement during treatment at home. This evaluation empowers the physician to monitor the subject's performance during in-home therapy and allow him/her to adjust the haptic and simulation in an appropriate fashion. This research hypothesizes that by using haptics the effectiveness of home-centered rehabilitation therapy is effective in empowering the patient. Moreover, it is contemplated that by cognitive monitoring of subjects, it is possible to evaluate and improve patient engagement during the therapy sessions.

por.por_cntn:
Despite significant improvements in the design of in-home robotic rehabilitation systems through the years, the success of these systems may not be necessarily superior to manual physical therapy unless there is an active engagement from the patient. Our project focused on designing a home-based cognitive haptic system that considers the human intention and physiological feedback in the control architecture of the robotic system. This human-in-the-loop rehabilitation system aimed to understand the human intention and his/her level of mental and physical engagement in the rehabilitation to automatically adjust the training and the robot controller to maximizes the patient's engagement and hence recovery.

For this purpose, we conducted an in-depth analysis of various physiological features including brain activities, muscle activities and kinematics of hand movements. Using a data-driven systematic approach, we created a cognitive model that can robustly estimate the cognitive engagement and workload of the patients while performing the physical task with the robot.

To assess the impact of the cognitive models in the adaptation of the rehabilitation systems, we conducted various human subject studies in which the human subjects were trained to learn a fine motor task in a writing haptic simulator. Our results provided a roadmap to select the best type of controller depending on the task performance and level of engagement for both dominant and non-dominant hand. We also conducted a set of validation studies in which the developed brain monitoring technique was successfully used to determine if the parameters of the robot's controller were adjusted properly with respect to the patient?s level of comfort and the task in hand. The methodology developed in this project represents a compelling strategy for the design and assessment of a broader class of physical human-robot interaction, in which safety and motor learning are the main concerns.

We used the lessons learned and the tools developed to (i) enhance graduate courses and laboratories with topics on physical human-robot interaction; (ii) train undergraduate and graduate interns on conducting research in human-in the loop system design and assessment; (iii) establish cross-institutional collaborations essential in delivering haptic and virtual reality training into the cognitive rehabilitation framework (iv) provide insights on the brain dynamics in physical interaction with the robotic systems that can be used in physical human-robot interaction applications beyond the robotic rehabilitation to increase the safety. This research grant provided partial support for three Ph.D. students.
